comments.commentBody:
~
~
Perhaps it's time to consider the reason he prefers his Florida property over Camp David is bcz Camp David is designed to keep track of who comes and goes making it far easier to have"secret" meetings in Florida at a cost of several million a weekend.

The Secret Service knows his every move, and that of anyone who comes within a 25 mile radius of his villa. When he's in town, the local airport has to go on lockdown. His trips are destroying the local economy. There aren't any secrets with the Secret Service. Though they keep mum.

It's probably true that Trump Tower was monitored and wiretapped (perhaps) by our intelligence agencies because of the overwhelming amount of verifiable evidence of encounters and communications, now publicly known, between Trump campaign staff and surrogates and members of Russian intelligence and Russian government officials before any of them would have been authorized to do so. And for purposes that are probably not in the best interest of the United States of America.

Our intelligence agencies job is to keep our country safe and obviously there was very strong and mounting reason to believe that this present administration is jeopardizing the very safety of our country.

Kind of just the opposite of what Trump promised in his campaigning and post election hyperbole.

His experience with reality TV has totally convinced him that every episode of his daily life must involve escalating drama that culminates right before the next commercial break [queue up photo ops at Mar-a-Lago, praise for his preferred media outlets, plugs for Ivanka's fashion line...], with a wild, unexpected cliffhanger to leave us dangling for his next misadventure. Maybe he really deserves an Emmy for creativity.
As Mencken observed, you'll never go broke betting against the intelligence of the American people.

There were safeguards put into place since Obama was caught in that lie. If they have been circumvented Trump needs to come out with more than a Breitbart conspiracy theory, and Breitbart needs to be called in for sources just as many others have been challenged from RESPECTABLE news agencies.

Let's suppose someone in the Obama administration tried to influence the election but found nothing.  That is much more likely, since if they found something it would have been found here in this excellent truthful news outlet.

If Trump becomes a yuuuuuuge drag on the party and the GOP majority congress finds it cannot achieve their goals, and if individual lawmakers find themselves in danger of losing their seats in the next election due to the antics of the President, they may go into self-survival mode and eject him in a heartbeat.  After all, it is all about the party.
When he tweets that the previous president tapped his phone, that's news.
I really hope you're right!
"Has there ever been as much havoc in the infant stages of a Presidency than this one?".  In my 67 years, none that I can recall, including Watergate.  But then, Nixon didn't have twitter.
I'm fairly sure that Trump's not capable of realizing that.
Well, which of his decisions have ever shown any good or reasonable judgement?!
the wheels are off his wagon. just waiting to see the wagon crash.
Mr. Trump should focus his attention on more pressing issues, e.g. finding the missing quart of frozen strawberries.
Best comment of the whole thread, John. I needed a good laugh about this.

It sounds like Trump knows that they have the goods on him and he is laying the groundwork, on the advise of one of his discount rate lawyers, to have the evidence deemed inadmissible on the basis it was gathered at Obama's direction acting as head of the government.

Trump has amassed a long track record of throwing out false allegations by this point; that is why people immediately dismiss this. If this were based on actual evidence, it certainly would have come through some more reliable channel than his twitter feed.

It might seem extreme to say this, but I believe we need to start thinking about  how to set up an interm gov that can step in when all this explodes in the coming weeks.  Trump's demise seems imminent, and Pence and Ryan will likely have to go as well, when the full story comes out; and, arguably, many other leading Repubs will also find themselves visibly compromised and unfit for governing.  The trick will be to try and make it a soft enough landing for Trump and Co., such that there isn't fighting in the streets.  In short, one can easily imagine a significant power-vacuum on the horizon, one that would represent a significant risk to our country and needs to be minimized at all costs.
God I pray Alan is right.
Calm yourself, Alan, we're all set up for an orderly transition of power.  We've done it before; we'll do it again.
I think it is fair to say that government of the people, by the people, for the people has now perished.

The "by the people and of the people" parts haven't yet perished. Remember a minority of my compatriots voted for Trump. I would venture to guess that in their narrowly focused world the "for the people" part is still valid too. It remains for Trump to burn down the Capitol then ask Congress for a suspension of the Constitution and indefinite permission to rule by decree for us to lose the whole thing. Stay tuned.
This is the classic tactic taught to Trump by Roy Cohen: When attacked, respond with an attack that is twice as strong, even when false.

Serving food like real tomatoes that "no one would want to eat"? For real?

If Michelle Obama grew a tomato, tomatoes are bad! Only highly processed chicken nuggets for American children!

Some children (probably quite a few in red states who live on family farms) can make intelligent choices about what they eat, and prefer food over chemicals. Maybe more adults should become more literate about real food.

But sure, blame the Obamas for making school lunches worse (how exactly?) by modeling gardening. Or let me guess, it's about the cost to the American taxpayer? I'd rather spend a dime on a tomato than 54 billion on the war this Administration can't wait to get us into.
Well put.

.
.
This quote was a bit on the difficult side, but many worthwhile things require that we work for them.

EMILY COX & HENRY RATHVON: Somerville has its claims to fame. Remember how revolutionary it was when Steve's offered Mix-Ins with the ice cream? Line around the block on a warm night. And of course, there's Tufts and their Jumbos. A member of Somerville's Auxiliary Police Dep't got himself a job at MIT, where he was killed by the Boston Marathon bombers. The bombers had a favorite restaurant and a favorite auto mechanic in Somerville.

But I hope you can accept the reality that PAGAN KENNEDY (nee PAmela) - with her Wesleyan degree and her Johns Hopkins Master's - may have the sound judgment to ignore the Boston Americans, or whatever they call themselves these days.

This genius author has expertise in how things work. How they truly work.

Denizens of the hard-hat zone known as Fenway Park, adorned with a right-field line whose precise length cannot be measured if team security stops the measurer in time, have expertise in the opposite of how things work. A piano in a cranberry bog causes baseball games to have predictable results? A team that plays 7 games against one of the strongest existing teams often ends up beaten by that strong team ... so that means someone put a curse on someone? Paraphernailia buried in the concrete foundation of a ballpark in another city are supposed to mean something?

Not to mention, Kevin KENNEDY wasn't treated too well by the club.
In this instance, Elementary means easy!

Perhaps many of the people, in Congress, who wish to criminalize contraception, do so for ideological reasons There will always be full-serviced physicians, and a trip to Canada is really not expensive these days.

That's part of the problem for the poor. Many OB/GYNs don't take Medicaid--some 72% in Texas don't--and the GOP, now empowered by Trump are even trying to de-fund Planned Parenthood--a non-profit, nationwide source of General Medical Care for Women, accepts medicate, provides family planning and, yes, abortions--but that's only three percent of what they do.

The attacks on Women's Health Care are multi-pronged. Many GOP-majority statehouses mandate abstinence only in high school sex ed, they didn't accept Extended Medicaid, and they have been passing laws that make it impossible for PPA to continue in business. Meanwhile, wealthy women can just go to their usual OB/GYN and access the very fullest range of Women's health Care, for them and their daughter(s). That includes Abortion.

This is what was so nefarious as to how they played with President Barack Obama's $1.9 Billion request to fight the Zika virus. Florida and Texas have Republican Fivers and majority Legislatures, didn't accept Extended Medicaid and, yet, women who'd newborns might have been endangered by the evil effects, had no option. In effect, they were told: Don't Get Pregnant!

Certainly no sage advice!

https://thetruthoncommonsense.com

Every American should be concerned about our President being duped by Fake News and then spreading it.

If he's this easily played by Bannon, then how will he react when there is a real crisis that requires firm decisiveness and action by the President? Since he has zero faith in U.S. intelligence agencies and in credible news sources, who will brief the President and how will he assemble factual information before acting?

Bannon?

Today's ridiculous tweets from Trump, including calling Mr. Obama "sick" reflect the mindset of a man with serious psychological maladies.

Our President doesn't need a health care bill or a new travel ban, he needs psychological help and treatment. It's difficult to believe that even the spineless GOP will tolerate this madness much longer.
